Or play the game “Existence” to the end
 Of the beginning, of the beginning

It’s fitting that these are the last lines, not only of the song, but of this remarkable album.

Alternative to the notion of listening to “the colour of your dreams,” Lennon—ever the non-conformist—uses rhetoric to dissuade the listener from playing the game of “existence”; which will only circle from beginning to end and end to beginning, like a Tibetan Knot:



According to The Beatles Bible and other sources, Lennon was inspired to write “Tomorrow Never Knows” after reading 1964’s The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based On The Tibetan Book Of The Dead, by Timothy Leary.
But listen to the colour of your dreams
Lennon seems to be invoking LSD-induced synesthesia—where users “taste” sounds or “hear” colors while under the influence.

Lay down all thoughts, surrender to the void
 It is shining, it is shining

According to the Beatles Bible, George Harrison had this to say about Lennon’s lyrics:


Then it says, ‘Lay down all thoughts, surrender to the void – it is shining. That you may see the meaning of within – it is being.’ From birth to death all we ever do is think: we have one thought, we have another thought, another thought, another thought. Even when you are asleep you are having dreams, so there is never a time from birth to death when the mind isn’t always active with thoughts. But you can turn off your mind, and go to the part which Maharishi described as: ‘Where was your last thought before you thought it?’

The whole point is that we are the song. The self is coming from a state of pure awareness, from the state of being. All the rest that comes about in the outward manifestation of the physical world (including all the fluctuations which end up as thoughts and actions) is just clutter. The true nature of each soul is pure consciousness. So the song is really about transcending and about the quality of the transcendent.
[Solo]

According to Ian MacDonald’s Revolution in the Head: The Beatles' Records & The Sixties, there are five prominent tape loops throughout “Tomorrow Never Knows”:

1.) A recording of McCartney’s laughter, sped up to resemble the sound of a seagull (enters at 0:07)
2.) An orchestral chord of B flat major (0:19)
3.) A Mellotron on its flute setting (0:22)
4.) A Mellotron strings sound, alternating between B flat and C in 6/8 time (0:38)
5.) A sitar playing a rising scalar phrase, recorded with heavy saturation and sped up (0:56)
It is believing, it is believing
Believing in love as the answer to life’s problems of hate and other negative emotions.
It is knowing, it is knowing
Love is the knowledge. Knowing love is the shining light and the secrets from within.
It is not living, it is not living

John is trying to capture an experience he had while tripping on acid and reading The Tibetan Book of the Dead:

John had got hold of Timothy Leary’s adaptation of The Tibetan Book of the Dead, which is a pretty interesting book. For the first time we got the idea that, as with ancient Egyptian practice, when you die you lie in state for a few days, and then some of your handmaidens come and prepare you for a huge voyage. Rather than the British version, in which you just pop your clogs. With LSD, this theme was all the more interesting.
- Paul McCartney
That love is all and love is everyone

The Beatles wrote many songs about love and believed in true love. As they wrote in “All You Need Is Love”, they came to believe that the meaning of life is love. Love is a common emotion everyone shares and it is a fundamental part of human existence. Thus love is everything, love is the meaning of life, and it is part of everyone.

That you may see the meaning of within
 It is being, it is being

By giving yourself to the void, by letting go of who you are and your conceptions of the world, you find real truth.

Of course it’s not for everyone.
